group_1.textRight: It's almost Valentine's Day.

group_1.textLeft: That's right.

group_1.textRight: Have you decided what chocolates – no, gifts –@you'll be getting for us?

group_1.textLeft: ...Yeah. I think I have it narrowed down.

group_1.textRight: *Giggle* I can't wait to see them.

group_1.narration: Komachi and I aren't really the sort of people@who care about the happenings of the world around us.
Instead, we usually discuss things@like the books we're reading.
But this morning,@we've been talking about Valentine's Day because...

group_1.textCenter: What are you guys doing for Valentine's Day?

group_1.textLeft: What are we doing for...?
Do you need help with something?

group_1.textRight: No, I mean...
Like, will you guys do a chocolate exchange?

group_1.textLeft: I've never considered that.
If I were to receive any gift, I'd prefer a book.

group_1.textRight: Come on, it'd be refreshingly normal!

group_1.textLeft: Sounds like you enjoy that sort of thing.

group_1.textRight: Yeah, I don't mind it! It's a good opportunity@for observations.

group_1.textLeft: Observations?

group_1.textRight: You see, someday I'd like to make a movie for@teenage girls, focusing on Valentine's Day.
I might even start taking footage for it!

group_1.textLeft: ...Wow. You think and behave in surprising ways.

group_1.textRight: That "surprising" was totally unnecessary!

group_1.textLeft: Yes, it was a slip of the tongue.
...Well, why not? Let's exchange chocolates with@each other.

group_1.textRight: How spontaneous! It's been a while since we've seen@that side of you.

group_1.textLeft: Perhaps someday I'd like to write a novel about@high schoolers and Valentine's Day as well.
I can't discount the possibility.

group_1.textRight: I can't imagine a future like that, but it'd be@interesting if it happened.
So on Valentine's Day, we're all okay with@exchanging chocolates after school?
Yeah, let's do it!

group_1.textLeft: Does it have to be limited to chocolate...?

group_1.textRight: ...Wait, you don't like chocolate?

group_1.textLeft: Quite the contrary.@I like it, but I'm very picky about it.

group_1.textRight: Coming from you, I get the feeling "very picky" is a@massive understatement...

group_1.textLeft: ...In that case, why don't we exchange gifts in@general, rather than just chocolate?

group_1.textRight: [chara:303901:effect_emotion_joy_0][se:7222_happy]I'm all for that!
So it'll be a Valentine's gift exchange instead of a@Valentine's chocolate exchange.

group_1.textLeft: But is that what Valentine's Day is really about...?

group_1.textRight: ...Actually, I have an idea of what you might want.

group_1.textLeft: I thought you would. We've known each other@for a long time.

group_1.narration: Recently, I've been looking for@an old book that's somewhat hard to come by -@the second volume of "The Boy Who Became a Coin."
I was searching for it at a used book store a little while ago.@Given how perceptive Komachi is, I'm sure she's noticed.

group_1.textRight: You seem to know exactly what you're getting@for me.
That means you probably know what I'd like, too,@right?

group_1.textLeft: Well, pretty much.

group_1.textRight: Still, I don't remember ever talking about what@I would want...

group_1.textLeft: We're better off not putting those things in words.
Words, at their essence, are boorish and inelegant.

group_1.textRight: Should you really be saying that? You practically@live for poetry and novels.

group_1.textLeft: Yes, that's precisely why I should say it.
The meaning of any word is unconstant@to begin with.
Not only do you have to consider the context@it appears in,
but it also changes according to the perception of@those who see or hear it.

group_1.textRight: Hmm...

group_1.textLeft: For example, imagine someone saying,@"What? It's 5:00 PM already?"
It could be conveying, "It's time to go home."
Or it could convey, "We've been having so much fun,@I lost track of time."
Something like, "He did the best he could" can be@the highest praise in some situations.
While in others, it would be cruel sarcasm.
The more words you use, the more likely@misunderstandings will occur.
To borrow a line from Hamlet,@"Words, words, words..."
When you've been writing for a long time,@you inevitably grow tired of them.

group_1.textRight: Seems like writing is hard work.

group_1.textLeft: There's a saying that you have to let your audience@read between the lines.
Ideally, you can get your message across with@just a few words.

group_1.textRight: I see...

group_1.textLeft: ...I know it's complicated, but to put it simply,@when it comes to gifts,
it's no fun to just tell people what you want@in advance.

group_1.textRight: We certainly got sidetracked.

group_1.textLeft: Well, I don't know about Mihono, but for you and I,
I'm sure we won't disappoint each other.

group_1.textRight: Do we really have that level of trust?

group_1.textLeft: Why don't we test my theory and see?
From now until Valentine's Day, I will not say@a single word.
[flashEffect:explosion][se:3201_heal]Even so—

group_1.narration: I must have accidentally cast a spell on myself.

group_1.textRight: Kira...?

group_1.textCenter: From now until Valentine's Day, I will not say@a single word.

group_1.textLeft: (I was so careless...)
